name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

output:

prompt:
Casimir holds a rectangular sheet with a checkered area measuring n × m. Initially, each cell within the area is white.

Let's label the cell using vertical coordinate i and horizontal coordinate j as (i, j). The cell at the top left will be labeled (1, 1), and the cell at the bottom right will be labeled (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of various sizes on the area. A tick of size d (d > 0) centered in cell (i, j) is created in the following manner:

Initially, the cell at the center (i, j) receives a black paint. This is the first step of creating a tick. 
Subsequently, exactly d cells in the top-left diagonal to the center and exactly d cells in the top-right diagonal to the center are also turned black. 
3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for every h ranging from 0 to d are painted. Specifically, a tick contains a total of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that's already painted will remain black if repainted. Below you can see an illustration of the 4 × 9 grid, showcasing two ticks with sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered area sized n × m. Casimir asserts that this area resulted from him drawing several ticks on it. The ticks might vary in sizes, but each tick size is at least k (meaning d ≥ k for every tick).

Establish whether this area can actually be formed by sketching some (potentially none) ticks with sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for painted cells and '.' for unpainted cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to track if a cell is part of a tick
        tick_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    if can_form_tick(i, j, k, n, m, grid, tick_grid):
                        mark_tick(i, j, k, tick_grid)

        # Verify if all '*' cells in the grid can be explained by the ticks formed
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or tick_grid[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], tick_grid: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): Grid representation.
        tick_grid (List[List[bool]]): Grid to track tick formation.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - h < 0 or j - h < 0 or j + h >= m:
            return False
        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, tick_grid: List[List[bool]]) -> None:
    """Mark cells as part of a tick in the tick grid.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Size of the tick.
        tick_grid (List[List[bool]]): Grid to track tick formation.
    """
    tick_grid[i][j] = True
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        tick_grid[i - h][j - h] = True
        tick_grid[i - h][j + h] = True

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the grid can be formed by drawing ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k or larger can be formed
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all painted cells can be part of valid ticks
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    def is_valid_tick_center(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[List[str]], i: int, j: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size at least k can be centered at (i, j)."""
        size = 0
        while True:
            if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                break
            if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                break
            size += 1
        return size > k

    def mark_tick(n: int, m: int, grid: List[List[str]], i: int, j: int, size: int) -> None:
        """Mark the cells of a tick centered at (i, j) with the given size."""
        for h in range(size):
            grid[i - h][j - h] = '.'
            grid[i - h][j + h] = '.'
        grid[i][j] = '.'

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and is_valid_tick_center(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                    size = 0
                    while i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*':
                        size += 1
                    mark_tick(n, m, grid, i, j, size - 1)

        if all(cell == '.' for row in grid for cell in row):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the checkered area can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                # Check if the current cell can be the center of a tick of size k
                valid_tick = True
                for h in range(k):
                    if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
                        valid_tick = False
                        break
                if valid_tick:
                    can_be_center[i][j] = True

        # Mark cells that can be part of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if can_be_center[i][j]:
                    for h in range(k + 1):
                        grid[i - h][j - h] = '.'
                        grid[i - h][j + h] = '.'

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    possible = False
                    break
            if not possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):

                            size += 1

                            break

                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are marked
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]) -> list[str]:
    """Determine if the grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (list[str]): Grid representation with '*' for painted cells and '.' for unpainted cells.

    Returns:
        list[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    def is_valid_tick_center(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: list[str], i: int, j: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size at least k can be centered at (i, j).

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            grid (list[str]): Grid representation.
            i (int): Row index of the center.
            j (int): Column index of the center.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a tick can be centered at (i, j), False otherwise.
        """
        for d in range(1, k + 1):
            if i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m:
                return False
            if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                return False
        return True

    def mark_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: list[str], i: int, j: int) -> None:
        """Mark the cells of a tick centered at (i, j) as part of a valid tick.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            grid (list[str]): Grid representation.
            i (int): Row index of the center.
            j (int): Column index of the center.
        """
        for d in range(k + 1):
            grid[i - d] = grid[i - d][:j - d] + '.' + grid[i - d][j - d + 1:j + d] + '.' + grid[i - d][j + d + 1:]

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        valid = True
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    if is_valid_tick_center(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                        mark_tick(n, m, k, grid, i, j)
                    else:
                        valid = False
                        break
            if not valid:
                break
        results.append('YES' if valid else 'NO')
    return results

# Input interface
num_cases = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(num_cases):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Call the function and print results
results = can_form_ticks(num_cases, test_cases)
for result in results:
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' and '.'.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that can be part of a valid tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a valid tick
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            can_be_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid can be covered by valid ticks
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    def is_valid_tick_center(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int, i: int, j: int, k: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size at least k can be centered at (i, j)."""
        size = 0
        while True:
            if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                break
            if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                break
            size += 1
        return size > k

    def mark_tick(grid: List[List[bool]], n: int, m: int, i: int, j: int, size: int):
        """Mark the cells of a tick centered at (i, j) with the given size."""
        for h in range(size):
            grid[i - h][j - h] = True
            grid[i - h][j + h] = True

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a boolean grid to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to find valid tick centers
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and is_valid_tick_center(grid, n, m, i, j, k):
                    # Determine the size of the tick
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                            break
                        if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                            break
                        size += 1
                    # Mark the tick in the boolean grid
                    mark_tick(marked, n, m, i, j, size)

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the grid can be formed by ticks of at least size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j)
                    if can_form_tick(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                        # Mark the cells as part of a tick
                        mark_tick(n, m, k, marked, i, j)

        # Check if all '*' cells are marked
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or marked[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], i: int, j: int) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation.
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m:
            return False
        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, marked: List[List[bool]], i: int, j: int):
    """Mark the cells as part of a tick centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells.
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.
    """
    marked[i][j] = True
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
        marked[i - d][j + d] = True

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Call the function and print results
results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    print(result)

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
